blogs.title: Let's go! The 12 Startups in 12 Months Challenge Starts Now
blogs.body:
What would you do if I gave you $1 million today on the condition that you invest it entirely in the stock market?

First off, you‚Äôd probably find someone who knows way more about investing and get some professional advice.

But in lieu of that, you‚Äôd divide your money among a variety of bets:

Stable companies with a history of profitability, growth-stage companies with a high tolerance for risk, and maybe a few companies you just personally believe have potential.

In short, you‚Äôd diversify.

The thought of putting all $1 million into a single company probably wouldn‚Äôt cross your mind.

Someday soon, I‚Äôd like to think a year of my time will be ‚Äúworth‚Äù more than $1 million. So I won‚Äôt be putting it all into a single company either.

Instead I‚Äôll build a startup a month for the next year.

Prior Art
The first person to popularize building 12 startups in 12 months is Pieter Levels, who launched products like NomadList and RemoteOK in 2014.

Since he operates both as open startups we know they make a combined $600,000 per year.

Not bad for a solo founder with a part-time sys admin.

In the 5 years since, several others have taken the same challenge.

Jon Yongfook started at the end of 2018, and eventually founded BannerBear. In the year he‚Äôs been working on it, it‚Äôs grown to $5.1K MRR (monthly recurring revenue).

When I was chatting with Dominic Monn about the idea, he told me he‚Äôs had success with this approach too:

I did something along the same lines where I launched 6 things in about 6 months in 2018 and two things grew out of it that make around $3.5k MRR together today, and some of the others I sold for a cumulative 5 figures as well.

The common thread is that no one doing the challenge completes it.

Building 12 startups isn‚Äôt actually the goal.

The goal is to eliminate the most common blockers from shipping a product: failure to stick to an MVP and finish something, fear of shipping, launching, charging money, and so forth.

Now, each of these things has to happen inside a month.

The idea is that a fixed timespan helps you quickly find a few ideas worthy of your undivided focus.

Instead of spending years working on an idea that won‚Äôt pan out.

I‚Äôm under no illusion that since Pieter‚Äôs very public success, a ton of people have undergone the same challenge.

Few, if any, have seen the same financial outcomes thus far. The majority still work their day jobs. And a quick search on Google reveals that most people don‚Äôt make it past the first 2-3 startups.

That‚Äôs why I‚Äôve adapted the challenge to tip the odds in my favor.

It‚Äôs dangerous to go alone
In Lost and Founder, Rand Fishkin, former CEO of Moz, writes:

That‚Äôs one of the biggest things I‚Äôve learned about startups: it‚Äôs dangerous to go alone. You want people around you who‚Äôve been through this before and are willing to openly share their experiences.

This is the main difference in our approach to building 12 startups in 12 months: We‚Äôre not going alone.

We‚Äôve created 12x Startup: A cohort of 4 motivated makers, each building their own ‚Äúone startup per month‚Äù.

Each day, we post our current task on our public status page. We correspond regularly in Slack, challenge each other‚Äôs ideas, and plan to livestream our monthly demo sessions for you to tune into.

blogs.title: 7 Absolute Truths I Unlearned as Junior Developer
blogs.body:
Next year, I‚Äôll be entering my 10th year of being formally employed to write code. Ten years! And besides actual employment, for nearly 2/3 of my life, I‚Äôve been building things on the web. I can barely remember a time in my life where I didn‚Äôt know HTML, which is kind of weird when you think about it. Some kids learn to play an instrument or dance ballet, but instead I was creating magical worlds with code in my childhood bedroom.

In reflecting on this first decade of getting regularly paid money to type weird symbols into my Terminal, I wanted to take some time to share some of the ways my thinking shifted over the years as a developer.

For today‚Äôs junior developers: Maybe you‚Äôll find something here you currently believe, and get inspired to learn more about it and why the topic is so multi-faceted. Or maybe you‚Äôll find this post encouraging because you‚Äôre already so far ahead of where I was at your stage.

For today‚Äôs senior developers: Maybe you can relate, and also have some funny (and humbling) stories to share about your own life lessons when you were a junior dev.

To be clear, I think junior developers are awesome and just showing up to learn already takes a ton of courage. This post is about my own journey and learnings, and isn‚Äôt meant to be a generalization about how all junior devs think or behave.

I hope you enjoy the post and can relate a little bit üòÑ

Thanks to Artem and Sara for your feedback on this post!

Absolute truths I unlearned as a junior developer
1. I‚Äôm a senior developer
I was 19 years old when I applied for my first technical job. The position I was applying for was called ‚ÄúStudent Webmaster‚Äù. Which is a pretty awesome job title, because you could be considered both a ‚Äústudent‚Äù and a ‚Äúmaster‚Äù at the same time. Nowadays everyone wants to be an ‚Äúengineer‚Äù because it sounds fancier, but if you ask me, ‚Äúmaster‚Äù is where it‚Äôs at. Anyways, my job was to write PHP and MySQL, and maintain our Drupal website as well as building some internal tools.

Since I‚Äôd been coding in my bedroom for a couple of years, I was pretty sure those years counted as ‚Äúyears of experience‚Äù. So when I was asked about how much experience I had writing PHP, I confidently answered, ‚Äú3 or 4 years!‚Äù

I thought I knew a lot about SQL because I could do outer joins üòé

And when I googled it, 3-4 years of experience meant I should be making üí∞

Fast forward to my latest job, which I got after 5 years of ‚Äúcombined‚Äù student and professional experience (which I thought was the same as normal experience). Yet in that time, I basically never had my code reviewed. I deployed by ssh-ing into a server and running git pull. I‚Äôm rather sure I never had to open a Pull Request. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, I learned a ton of awesome stuff at my first two jobs, but I‚Äôd never really worked with other devs in the same codebase. And yet, I applied for a position for ‚ÄúSenior Frontend Engineer‚Äù, got an offer, and accepted it.

There I was, a senior developer at the ripe age of 24 years old.

I mean they wouldn‚Äôt have given me this job title if I wasn‚Äôt really senior, right?! Surely, my impressive experience had brought me to this point, and people should listen to me!! Already at the pinnacle of my technical career, and the youngest developer in the office.

Like a boss üíÖ

What I eventually learned
Not all experience is created equal. My experience coding in my bedroom, working as a student, working in CS research, and working at a growing startup are all valuable kinds of experience. But they aren‚Äôt all the same. Early in your career, you can learn 10x more in a supportive team in 1 year, than coding on your own (or with minimal feedback) for 5 years. If your code is never reviewed by other developers, you will not learn as fast as you can ‚Äì by an enormous factor.

That‚Äôs why mentors are so important, and the team you work with is worth so much more than a couple bucks in your paycheck. Don‚Äôt accept a junior position where you‚Äôll be working alone, if you can help it! And don‚Äôt accept your first role (or, honestly, any role) based on salary alone. The team is where the real value is.

I also learned that job titles don‚Äôt ‚Äúmake‚Äù you anything. It‚Äôs kind of like, being a CTO with a 5-person team is different than with a 50-person team or a 500-person team. The job and skills required are totally different, even if the title is identical. So just because I had a ‚Äúsenior‚Äù job title did not make me a senior engineer at all. Furthermore, hierarchical titles are inherently flawed, and difficult to compare cross-company. I learned it‚Äôs important not to fixate on titles, or use them as a form of external validation.

2. Everyone writes tests
For the first half of my career, I worked in research. Specifically, I worked on an publicly-funded project for about 3 1/2 years, and then at a university at the NLP chair for a year and a half. I can tell you one thing: programming in research is completely different than programming in the industry.

For the most part, you aren‚Äôt building applications. You‚Äôre working on algorithms or parsing data sets. Alternatively, if you are building an application, chances are your work is being publicly funded ‚Äì which means it‚Äôs free for others to use and usually open-source. And when something is free, that means, for the most part, you are not really responsible to make sure it‚Äôs always perfectly available.

Because, well, it‚Äôs free.

You‚Äôre also not responsible to make any money or produce results, but that is an entirely different blog post ranting about being a developer in academia ‚ú®

Long story short, I left academia with lots of expectations.

Expectations about how the industry would work. There would be automated deployment. Pull requests and code review. It was going to be glorious! Finally the code quality I had been longing for! But beyond quality code with proper standards and best practices, I strongly believed, everyone in the software industry writes tests.

Ahem.

So imagine my surprise when I showed up at my first day on the job at a startup and found no tests at all. No tests in the frontend. No tests in the backend. Just, no tests.

Nada. Zip. Null. Undefined. NaN tests.

Not only were there no tests, but no one seemed to have a problem with the lack of tests! With a bit of naivety, I assumed the reason there were no tests was because people just didn‚Äôt know how to write tests for AngularJS. If I taught them how, everything would be OK and we‚Äôd start to have tests. Wrong! Long story short, years and years later, we‚Äôve made huge progress on adding automated tests to our code, and it wasn‚Äôt as straightforward as I thought it would be.

But not because people didn‚Äôt know how to write the tests.

They‚Äôd either never felt the pain of not having tests, or they‚Äôd felt the pain of having legacy tests. Two things I‚Äôd never experienced for myself.

What I eventually learned
Loads of companies and startups have little or no tests. When struggling to find product market fit, or fighting for survival, a lot of companies neglect testing early on. Even companies that look fancy, sponsoring conferences or open-sourcing code ‚Äì so many still have a big, gnarly monolith with minimal tests they need your help to improve. Ask devs who aren‚Äôt trying to recruit you to tell you about the state of the codebase.

No company has a perfect tech setup. Every company has problems, every company has technical debt. The question is what they‚Äôre doing about it. We should have no illusions when applying for jobs that there is work to be done ‚Äì or else they wouldn‚Äôt be hiring üòâ

Being overly opinionated on topics you lack real-world experience with is pretty arrogant. I came across as SUCH a know-it-all, insisting there must be tests yet having hardly any experience on what that really looked like at scale. Don‚Äôt be like me. It‚Äôs important to have principles, but also to be open and truly interested to understand other people‚Äôs experiences and perspectives.

3. We‚Äôre so far behind everyone else (AKA ‚Äútech FOMO‚Äù)
This one is closely related to the topic of unit testing. While my company didn‚Äôt have many unit tests, surely all the other companies did, right?

I read so many blog posts. I watched conference talks on YouTube. I read ‚Äúthat orange website‚Äù all the damn time. It seemed like everyone was writing super sophisticated and high-quality applications with great performance and fancy animations, while I was just over here patching some stuff together trying to make it work in time for my deadline.

I basically idolized all the other companies I was reading about, and felt disappointment that my own company and project was so behind.

What I eventually learned
Many conference talks cover proof of concepts rather than real-world scenarios. Just because you see a conference talk about a specific technology, doesn‚Äôt mean that company is using that tech in their day to day work, or that all of their code is in perfect shape. Often people who give conference talks are presenting toy apps rather than real-world case studies, it‚Äôs important to distinguish the two.

Dealing with legacy is completely normal. No but seriously, it‚Äôs easy to imagine that some other company doesn‚Äôt have legacy to handle. But after spending time at conferences talking to people who work at tippy top tech companies, it becomes clear that we are all in the same boat. What company DOESN‚ÄôT have a huge PHP or Ruby monolith they‚Äôre trying to tame (or had to tame at some point)? Legacy code is normal, and learning to deal with it will often teach you more than building apps from scratch because you‚Äôll be more exposed to concepts you don‚Äôt understand yet.

4. Code quality matters most
Back in the day, getting a code review from me could be brutal.

At least, I was really nitpicky about coding style. MY coding style, which happened to be a modified version of the Airbnb JavaScript styleguide, but conforming to my personal tastes. Things like indendetation, formatting, naming ‚Äì god forbid you did it differently than I would have. Passing a code review without at least one comment would have involved both mind-reading and winning the lottery.

Imagine 50+ comments on your PR with all the semicolons you missed!

Because I had eyes like an eagle and this eagle wants those high-quality semicolons ü¶Ö

(Luckily I no longer have eagle eyes after staring at the computer for many years, so you‚Äôre all spared ‚Äì #kiddingnotkidding)

What I eventually learned
Good enough is good enough. There‚Äôs a degree of diminishing returns when it comes to how ‚Äúgood‚Äù code needs to be. It doesn‚Äôt have to be perfectly clean to get the job done and not be a total disaster to maintain. Often code that is a little more repetitive or a tiny bit more verbose is easier for other people to understand. Also, ‚Äúgood code‚Äù is not the same as ‚Äúcode that looks like I wrote it‚Äù.

Architecture is more important than nitpicking. While a small line of code could be improved, the stuff that tends to cause bigger problems down the line are usually architectural. I should‚Äôve focused more on the structure of the application than tiny bits of code early on.

Code quality is important, don‚Äôt get me wrong. But code quality wasn‚Äôt what I thought it was, which was things like linting and formatting or whatever style was promoted in the latest blog post I had read üôà

5. Everything must be documented!!!!
When I entered my first company, it was honestly the first time I was working a lot with code other people had written. Sure, I had done it a little bit at my first job, but I never really had to come into an existing codebase and to figure out what the heck was going on. That‚Äôs because the one time that happened, I rewrote all the code instead of trying to figure out how it worked.

Anyways.

It didn‚Äôt help that it was AngularJS code written by Ruby developers, or that I was a junior developer who didn‚Äôt know she was junior üïµüèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

So how did I handle the fact that 300 lines of unfamiliar code made me feel like I was drowning?

JSDOC. EVERYWHERE.

I started commenting everything just to try to make sense out of it. Annotations for every function I could get my hands on.

I learned all that fancy Angular-specific JSDoc syntax. My code was always twice as long because it had so much documentation and so many comments üëå

What I eventually learned
Documentation lies sometimes. It‚Äôs easy to think that documentation is a cure-all solution. ‚ÄúWe need docs!‚Äù While I didn‚Äôt come to the conclusion that just because documentation is hard work, doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs not worth doing at all, I learned that you have to document the right things in the right way. Over-documentation of the wrong things tends to lead to staleness, which can be just as confusing to people who are trying to fix an issue.

Focus on automation over documentation where appropriate. Tests or other forms of automation are less likely to go out of sync. So instead I try to focus on writing good tests with clear language, so developers working on code I wrote are able to see how the project functions with working code. Another example is automating the installation of an application with a few comments, rather than a long and detailed installation guide.

6. Technical debt is bad
If you thought I was neurotic from the last point, just wait until this one! For a while in my career, I thought that any code I considered ‚Äúmessy‚Äù was in fact technical debt. Technical debt is a funny term because if you ask people to give you an example of what it is, there are so many different things that it could be.

So as someone who viewed any kind of ‚Äúdisorderly‚Äù code as technical debt, I immediately tried to eliminate it with the utmost rigor!

I literally once spent a weekend manually fixing 800 linting errors.

That‚Äôs how neurotic I was.

(Disclaimer: This was before auto-fixing was a thing)

What I eventually learned
Disorganized or messy code isn‚Äôt the same as technical debt. Just because something doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúfeel nice‚Äù doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs technical debt. Technical debt actually slows you down in some way, or makes certain kinds of changes difficult or error prone. If the code is just a little messy, it‚Äôs just a little messy. Tidying that up might not be worth my time.

Having some technical debt is healthy. Sometimes we take a shortcut because we need to borrow time, and for that we give up some of our speed in the future. Having pieces of code that are in fact ‚Äútechnical debt‚Äù is okay, so long as you recognize you‚Äôll likely need to pay that debt back. If you think your codebase is free of technical debt, there is a good chance you‚Äôre over-emphasizing polish instead of delivery. And boy did I do that!

7. Seniority means being the best at programming
Having started at a rather young age to code, I‚Äôve probably been proficient at doing for-loops for like 15+ years. Programming itself is like breathing to me. When a solution is apparent, I can just type away and the code will follow. It‚Äôs like writing a blog post or an email. I could code the solution faster than others, and typically took on the more complex projects for myself.

For a long time I thought that was what it meant to to be a senior developer.

Because why not? The job title is ‚Äúsenior developer‚Äù, not ‚Äúsenior communicator‚Äù or ‚Äúsenior project manager‚Äù. I didn‚Äôt really understand how many other skills I could possibly need to develop in order to be truly senior.

What I eventually learned
Senior engineers must develop many skills besides programming. The sheer number of skills I‚Äôve had to develop in the mean time are astronomical, compared to what I came in with. Ranging from communication and dependency management to sharing context, project management, estimation, and successfully collaborating with non-developer peers. These skills are less quantifiable and take a lot of trial and error to get right.

Not everyone will become ‚Äúsenior‚Äù during their career. Seniority is the result of many accrued years of experience. And yet, years of experience is a necessary but not sufficient condition for seniority. It also has to be the right kind of experience in which you internalized the right lessons and successfully apply those learnings for the future. Sometimes bigger lessons can take a year or more to fully manifest ‚Äì that‚Äôs why years of experience still matter, even if you‚Äôre a really good coder.

We‚Äôre all still junior in some areas. No matter how much experience you have, there are still places where you don‚Äôt know much. Admitting what you don‚Äôt know is the first step to filling in that gap and getting help from people who are more experienced.

blogs.title: 7 Software Developer Resume Tips to Help You Stand Out
blogs.body:
I‚Äôve read thousands of resumes and CVs during my 3+ years as a hiring manager at a high-growth tech startup.

It‚Äôs the same at many companies:

Most applications land in the bin at the stage where your resume or CV is all the company knows about you.

The reason for this is more or less mathematical: It‚Äôs simply impossible to speak to every single applicant. The time of hiring managers, tech recruiters, and everyone involved in any given hiring process is finite.

Popular roles can receive hundreds or thousands of candidates.

To top it off, companies are pretty much never recruiting for one role at a time. Hiring managers and tech recruiters are usually juggling numerous roles simultaneously. Hiring managers will have their own roles to fill, and may be involved in hiring processes of other managers as well.

That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs so important for your application to stand out amid the masses.

Luckily, it‚Äôs not that hard to do.

You can stand out simply by avoid a few painfully common mistakes, and learning a bit about how hiring processes actually work from the perspective of an employer.

Read on for tips on standing out with your resume in the competitive developer job market.

My experience as a hiring manager
Just to give you a quick idea about my background, which you‚Äôre welcome to skip if you don‚Äôt care (hey, some people will take advice from anyone on the internet, you do you).

I‚Äôm an American software engineer and former hiring manager, based in Berlin, Germany. There are a couple of unique aspects to this, such as dealing with visas, immigration guidelines, and working in an international environment ‚Äì all of which can impact the best way to put together a CV. I won‚Äôt cover that in this blog post, but feel free to let me know on Twitter (@monicalent) if you‚Äôd like CV tips specifically for applying for tech jobs in Germany.

Here‚Äôs how I‚Äôve been involved with hiring processes:

I‚Äôve done evaluations of candidates at all steps of a typical hiring process, from recruitment, job fairs, and cold outreach, to CV/resume screening and technical interviews, cultural fit interviews, salary negotiation, and everything in between. I‚Äôve hired just about every level of individual contributor role, ranging from juniors and interns to senior engineers, across the tech stack. I‚Äôve also interviewed engineering managers and VPs though that‚Äôs less relevant to this article.

During that time, I worked either independently as a hiring manager managing my own hiring process end-to-end, or in tandem with a technical recruiter. I have experience working with both in-house recruitment teams and outsourced recruitment agencies.

With that out of the way, let‚Äôs get to the tips üöÄ


Disclaimer: This blog post represents my opinions, not those of any employer I‚Äôve had, past or present. I will use this disclaimer to be able to give you my more or less unfiltered opinion on how to practically fix your developer resume or CV so you make it to the next stage.

Thanks to Steven, Carolyn, Christian, and Agnes for feedback on this post.

7 Software developer resume tips to help you stand out
For the purpose of this post, I‚Äôll be using ‚Äúresume‚Äù and ‚ÄúCV‚Äù interchangeably.

Here in Germany, it‚Äôs perfectly acceptable to submit a multi-page CV for an application (so long as it‚Äôs not full of fluff), whereas in the United States you may be expected to fit everything on one page.

It doesn‚Äôt really matter with regards to these tips, because the most important information should be on the first page anyways üòâ

1. For the love of God, use a spell checker
Anecdotally, I can tell you that having a CV with proper spelling and decent grammar will make you stand out from 90% of candidates who don‚Äôt.

Now, I‚Äôm not talking about the kinds of minor English mistakes which are common with people who speak English as a second language. That‚Äôs just the reality of working in an international environment, and it‚Äôs not a deal breaker whatsoever. Frankly I‚Äôve seen native speakers with as many or more errors than non-native speakers.

Avoiding typos and grammatical mistakes might sound trivial, but get this:

An analysis by Interviewing.io, a hiring platform for engineers, found that "typos and grammatical errors matter more than anything else" with regards to the success of a candidate.

But that analysis wasn‚Äôt just about passing the preliminary CV screening.

Lack of typos and grammatical errors were the leading indicator that a candidate gets a job offer.

Why do you think that is?

It‚Äôs probably not because final hiring decisions are made based on a vague memory of the candidate‚Äôs immaculate, typo-free CV.

My personal hypothesis is that having a CV without typos and grammatical mistakes is a byproduct of the candidate paying attention to details and having good communication skills.

Of all the tips on this list, this one is probably the easiest to implement.

Solution: Ask a friend (or two) to proofread
Besides getting your bff Clippy (or Grammarly) to help you fix typos and spelling mistakes, try reading your CV out loud or asking a friend to proofread it and tell you if it makes sense.

Sometimes when you spend hours working on something, it‚Äôs easy to become blind to mistakes because your brain fills in the gaps subconsciously.

Making sure you don‚Äôt have typos or grammatical errors in your CV is some of the best time you can spend working on it.

2. Make your resume concise and easy to scan
Remember how I said that hiring managers and technical recruiters don‚Äôt have a lot of time?

That means it‚Äôs your job to make it dead simple to figure out whether you‚Äôre a potential fit for the role after about 5-7 seconds of reading your CV.

You read me right. That‚Äôs how long a recruiter typically spends reading a CV according to an eye-tracking study.

If you look like a potential match, they might spend a little longer looking at your projects, checking out your website, and trying to understand better how you might fit into the existing team.

If you have long paragraphs with information buried in there, there‚Äôs a good chance it‚Äôll get passed over by mistake. Keep your sentences short, simple, direct, and easy to scan.

From the first 5 seconds, a recruiter or hiring manager should be able to figure out:

How much practical, professional experience do you have?
What technologies are you the most comfortable with?
What exactly did you do in your most recent role?
Do you match the requirements of the job position being advertised?
Skilled recruiters can and will assess this in a very short amount of time.

Tips for making your resume easy to scan
Use bullet points when possible. The simplest thing I can propose to you is to stick with bullet points when possible, and keeping those sentences really short (no more than 2 lines of text).

Mind the maximum width for readability. Bullet points won‚Äôt help if the width of your paragraphs or lists are too wide. 70-75 characters is the maximum.

Use active voice and simple grammar. Be direct and concise. Talk about the impact. Make it straightforward to figure out what you actually did (or are doing) at your latest job.

Use bold text to offset important information. See how I‚Äôm doing that in this blog post? You can do that on your CV. One way I‚Äôve personally done this is to include the technologies I actively used below the bullet point summary of my responsibilities in a certain position.

For example:

Skills and technologies: Angular.js, Koa.js, Webpack, Karma, Protractor

3. Don‚Äôt list every single technology you‚Äôve ever touched
Speaking of being concise, you know what‚Äôs not concise?

A gigantic, comma-separated list of every single technology you‚Äôve ever heard of.

Some people might tell you that this is how you get past ‚Äúalgorithms‚Äù that look for a specific technology in your resume.

I don‚Äôt know how true that is, but I can tell you that once a human looks at it, it comes across like you lack depth in any field, preferring to dabble in a bit of everything.

Even if that‚Äôs not true, guess what?

Recruiters and hiring managers don‚Äôt have time to figure out whether one of those 50 technologies on your CV is something you‚Äôre competent with.

If they‚Äôre desperate, you might get an email back asking for a phone screen. If you‚Äôre lucky, they might go searching your GitHub account to try to figure out which technologies you‚Äôre actually proficient in.

But if they have dozens of other candidates with more focused resumes, your application will end up in the bin.

Solution: List technologies you‚Äôre comfortable discussing in an interview
Stick to a smaller number of technologies you‚Äôd be comfortable working with.

If you feel it‚Äôs important to list technologies you‚Äôve been exposed to (let‚Äôs say you‚Äôre a junior developer or early in your career), you can denote which ones you are proficient in and which you‚Äôve used passively. For example:

Proficient: HTML, CSS, JavaScript, ReactJS, Jest, and Webpack
Familiar: Rollup, Redis, and Jenkins

But please, limit the number of technologies. No one expects you to be an expert in a dozen technologies.

Make it clear what you know well, so they can ask you relevant questions and you can sound smart (and feel comfortable) in a phone screen.

Questions can come up on just about anything on your CV, even if it‚Äôs not immediately related to job you‚Äôre applying for.

4. Actually read the job description. Then prove that you did.
You‚Äôd be surprised how many applications leave a recruiter or hiring manager wondering:

‚ÄúDid this person read the job ad?‚Äù

There are three main possibilities that come to mind for how this can happen:

You‚Äôre looking to switch your focus from whatever‚Äôs currently on your CV
You don‚Äôt understand the role being advertised and aren‚Äôt a fit for the role
You actually didn‚Äôt read the job ad
It doesn‚Äôt really matter which one of these it is. If you send in an ‚Äúirrelevant‚Äù resume for a job, and don‚Äôt include any context, it‚Äôs usually the end of the road.

Again, you can‚Äôt forget that you may be 1 of hundreds or thousands of candidates, and this post is about how to stand out.

In a sea of applicants, they may not have the time or capacity to follow up and ask you why exactly you thought you were a fit for the role.

Solution: Do some light customization of your application for the role
If you‚Äôre in the position where you‚Äôre looking to shift from one tech stack to another, make that clear in your application. Mention your desire to change, and the steps you‚Äôve taken to learn the new skills required (a link to a GitHub repository would be helpful).

Otherwise, if you‚Äôve done your research, move on to the next tip about how to make it clearer that you‚Äôve read the job description and done the tiniest bit of research about the company you‚Äôre applying for.

Last but not least, visit the company‚Äôs website and go into the interview with a basic understanding of what they do.

5. Write a customized cover letter
Even if you think you have a highly relevant CV, you should still consider writing a cover letter. It doesn‚Äôt have to be long, but it can only increase your chances of passing the CV screening phase.

Why?

I hate to be the one to tell you this, but it‚Äôs true:

Companies you‚Äôre applying for want to feel a little bit special. Like if they were to offer you a job, there‚Äôs a good chance you‚Äôd actually accept it.

Why? Well, because interviewing just one person takes hours of people‚Äôs time! And why should they invest hours in scheduling, interviewing, and discussing your application if you‚Äôre just as likely to accept any other position?

Trust me.

You will stand out if you have a coherent cover letter that demonstrates you‚Äôve read the job ad and the website.

It doesn‚Äôt have to be long, either. In fact, it shouldn‚Äôt be long, because ain‚Äôt nobody got time to read a super long cover letter. Just don‚Äôt forget to spell check üòâ

Tip: Basic elements of a cover letter for a developer role
Cover letters are extremely useful for standing out as a candidate for a number of reasons. Here‚Äôs a quick checklist of things you should demonstrate in your cover letter:

Show off your good communication skills
Demonstrate an understanding of the role
Briefly explain your qualifications and why you think you‚Äôre a good fit
Mention the company name
Demonstrate that you read the company‚Äôs website
Bonus tip: Attach the cover letter as a PDF
It‚Äôs just easier to read than pretty much any text format that could be typed into a web interface. Again, optimizing for ease of reading.

Note: Some companies may not find the cover letter useful or even read them. This can vary based on the role ‚Äì for a typical dev job, perhaps not. But for highly competitive junior roles or very senior roles, your motivation is relevant. In the end, a cover letter will never hurt you, and has the possibility to help you stand out.

6. Make it easy to find your work
Not everyone has time (or desire) to code for hours after work. Frankly, I don‚Äôt spend any more time coding than I need to.

But if you‚Äôre early in your career or looking to make a career switch, it is extremely important to have something to share besides a CV with a couple of buzzwords on it.

But even more important than having it: MAKE IT EASY TO FIND.

I can‚Äôt tell you how much effort I‚Äôve put into searching for people‚Äôs GitHub accounts, copy-pasting URLs with typos in them, all to try and find a reason to pass the person to the next stage of the process.

But a lot of CVs don‚Äôt make that easy!

If you‚Äôve put in the effort to have any openly available code, blog posts, a website, or anything public at all ‚Äì make it easy to access.

Solution: Hyperlinks to blog posts, GitHub repos, your website, etc.
This seems basic, but learn how to make your PDF resume or CV actually hyperlink to a website. Go through all the links and actually click on them to make sure they aren‚Äôt broken!

Remember: recruiters and managers have a limited amount of time. The easier you can make it for them to see what you can do, the faster they can pass you to the next round üëçüèº

7. Focus on projects and results over formal education
I‚Äôm going to preface this with the disclaimer that it‚Äôs totally possible there are recruiters or managers who may have a preference for graduates from a specific school.

I‚Äôm not saying you shouldn‚Äôt mention your degree or education.

Especially when applying for jobs in another country where your education may be a key factor in helping you land a work visa.

But in my experience, junior developers or developers early in their career tend to over-emphasize their education instead of practical, hands-on projects that demonstrate coding ability.

For example, here‚Äôs a grand list of things that don‚Äôt tell me if you can code well:

The grades or GPA you got in school
Which school you attended, or what you studied
What your class rank was
Which bootcamp you attended
That you attended a bootcamp at all
Pretty much anything related to formal education
It‚Äôs not that those things don‚Äôt matter at all. But they are a very weak indicator of whether you‚Äôre actually good at writing software. If you‚Äôve sat in on pretty much any Computer Science class, you might notice that having a CS degree does not indicate ability to program.

Beyond that, the market has become flooded with bootcamp graduates at all levels of skill. Just like having a degree, it doesn‚Äôt speak for itself whether you learned how to code.

Solution: Focus on what you‚Äôve built and its business impact
This can come in a number of forms. Working code is always great, but a well-written blog post or even just a concise and clear explanation on your CV is usually sufficient.

You can use some popular formulas to express your impact:

Built (project, feature) in order to (achieve something) using (technologies).
Increased (metric) by (amount) through (technical implementation).
Integrated (technologies) by (strategy) in order to (outcome).
Be specific, and avoid including points where it‚Äôs not clear whether you accomplished them yourself or passively participated in a process.

At the same time, be truthful about your role, responsibilities, and title. Don‚Äôt exaggerate. Being untruthful during the process is one of the quickest ways to get disqualified from a position.

Last point on describing your experience: while side projects and initiatives are great, they are mostly there as a supplement ‚Äì not a replacement ‚Äì for your accomplishments in your current role.

blogs.title: Responsive Images With Nginx on Ubuntu
blogs.body:
I started looking into this topic because, as you‚Äôve probably heard, Google changed its pagespeed insights tool (and search ranking algorithm) to focus on mobile-first. I‚Äôve got an image-heavy blog that does pretty well in Google, but my pagespeed score was somewhere between 75 and 80. One of Google‚Äôs biggest complaints to me were that my images were not resized properly.

The only problem is I have hundreds of images on that blog, and there was no way on earth I was going to actually create mobile-friendly versions of every single image.

Nginx to the rescue! Nginx has a neat module called image_filter which will do the work for you and resize images on the fly. This is awesome because it means you also only resize the images people are requesting instead of all the images.

blogs.title: Firebase Machine Learning is a mobile SDK that brings Google's machine learning expertise to Android and iOS apps
blogs.body: Firebase Machine Learning is a mobile SDK that brings Google's machine learning expertise to Android and iOS apps in a powerful yet easy-to-use package. Whether you're new or experienced in machine learning, you can implement the functionality you need in just a few lines of code. There's no need to have deep knowledge of neural networks or model optimization to get started. On the other hand, if you are an experienced ML developer, Firebase ML provides convenient APIs that help you use your custom TensorFlow Lite models in your mobile apps.

blogs.title: Introduction to Asynchronous Programming with JavaScript
blogs.body:
Your plan was to drink some tea while you read a book. However, when you were about to start, you noticed that there was no sugar for the tea. Instead of completely aborting your plan, you send for some sugar, keep aside the tea and begin reading. When the sugar arrives, you are notified. You pause reading, mix up the tea with the sugar, and go back to your initial plan.

This is an Asynchronous Pattern. JavaScript inherently supports Async programming patterns with something known as Callbacks. Going back to our analogy, you were "called back" when your sugar arrived. You then proceeded to mix them up together.

Callbacks in JavaScript works kind of in the same way. These are functions which contains instructions/statements you want to run after the Asynchronous process is resolved. A callback is the unit of Asynchrony. When you see a callback in a code, know that part will not resolve immediately.
